{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Igor Ivanovich Akimushkin | image = Akimushkin_Igor_Ivanovich.jpg | image_size = 275px | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1929|05|02}} | birth_place = [[Moscow]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1993|01|01|1929|05|02}} | death_place = [[Moscow]] | residence = [[Soviet Union]]
[[Russia]] | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = [[Biologist]], [[Writer]] | years_active = | known_for = the author of popular scientific books about the life of animals (Six-volume series «The World of Animals») | notable_works = | education = [[Candidate of Sciences]] | alma_mater = {{Moscow University|1952}} | employer = [[Shirshov Institute of Oceanology|Institute of Oceanology]] }} '''Igor Ivanovich Akimushkin''' ({{lang-ru|link=no|Игорь Иванович Акимушкин}}) (May 1, 1929 – 1993) was a Soviet [[zoologist]] and writer. Born in Moscow, he graduated the biological faculty of [[Moscow State University]] in 1952. His first books, ''Tracks of beast you never met'' and ''Following the Legends'', were published in 1961.{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} Igor Akimushkin wrote a large number of popular science books and made a significant contribution to science and made some discoveries by exploring the marine life. Most of his works were translated to other languages. The [[squid]] ''[[Cycloteuthis akimushkini]]'' was named in honour of Igor Akimushkin in 1968 by fellow zoologist [[Filippova]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tmbl.gu.se/libdb/taxon/personetymol/index.htm|title=BEMON|publisher=}} His most well known work is the six volume ''World of Animals''.{{Cite news|url=http://healthymax.org/who-you-are-igor-akimushkin-birthday-great-popularizer/|title=Who you are - Igor Akimushkin? Birthday great popularizer — HealthyMax|date=2017-01-27|work=HealthyMax|access-date=2017-10-03|language=en-US}} He worked at the [[Shirshov Institute of Oceanology|Shirshov Institute of Oceanology, Russian Academy of Sciences]]. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.litagent.ru/english/cliinfo.asp?KAvt=802 FTM Agency, Ltd] * [http://www.rgdb.ru/archiv/akimush.asp Игорь Иванович Акимушкин] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Akimushkin, Igor Ivanovich}} [[Category:1929 births]] [[Category:1993 deaths]] [[Category:Soviet zoologists]] [[Category:Soviet marine biologists]] [[Category:Soviet writers]] [[Category:Teuthologists]] [[Category:20th-century zoologists]] [[Category:Moscow State University alumni]] {{Russia-scientist-stub}} {{zoologist-stub}}

page.title: Invasive species in the United States

revision.text:
[[File:Brown tree snake (Boiga irregularis) (8387580552).jpg|thumb|The brown tree snake (''Boiga irregularis''), an invasive species in the United States.]] '''[[Invasive species]]''' are a significant threat to many native habitats and species of the [[United States]] and a significant cost to agriculture, forestry, and recreation. The term "invasive species" can refer to [[introduced species|introduced or naturalized species]], [[feral|feral species]], or introduced diseases. There are many species that are invasive. Some species, such as the [[Taraxacum officinale|dandelion]], while non-native, do not cause significant economic or ecologic damage and are not widely considered as invasive. Overall, it is estimated that 50,000 non-native species have been introduced to the United States, including livestock, crops, pets, and other non-invasive species. Economic damages associated with invasive species' effects and control costs are estimated at $120 billion per year.<ref>David Pimentel, Rodolfo Zuniga, Doug Morrison. Update on the environmental and economic costs associated with alien-invasive species in the United States. Ecological Economics. 52 (2005) 273-288.</ref>
[[Image:Kudzu on trees in Atlanta, Georgia.jpg|right|thumb|[[Kudzu]], a Japanese vine species invasive in the southeast United States, growing in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]].]]
==Notable invasive species== For a more complete list of invasive species, see [[List of invasive species in North America]]
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Picture !! Common Name !! Species Name !! style="width:100pt;"| Introduced !! style="width:100pt;"| Control Measures !! Notes |- | [[Image:Kudzu4903.JPG|100px]] || [[Kudzu]] || ''Pueraria lobata'' || Southern U.S. || Mowing, herbicides, [[conservation grazing]] || Known as "the vine that ate the south", forms dense [[monoculture]]s that outcompete native ground cover and forest trees. Can grow by up to one foot a day. |- || [[File:Tumbleweed_038.jpg|100px]] || [[Kali tragus|Common tumbleweed]] || ''[[Kali tragus]]'' || Throughout North America || Managed grazing || Introduced through imported flaxseed from Russia that was contaminated with ''Kali'' seeds. Although invasive, it was used in [[Western (genre)|Westerns]] to symbolize frontier areas of the United States. |- | [[File:LigustrumLucidumFlowers.jpg|100px]] || [[Privet]] || ''Ligustrum'' spp. || Southeastern U.S. || Mechanical removal, herbicides || Highly invasive in urban areas and forested area of the southeastern U.S. |- || [[File:Dreissena polymorpha3.jpg|100px]] || [[Zebra mussels]] || ''Dreissena polymorpha'' || Great Lakes, U.S. waterways & lakes || Ballast water transport bans, manual removal from clogged pipes || Initially spread by ballast tanks of oceangoing vessels on the Great Lakes, now spread lake-to-lake by trailer-drawn boats. May be a source of [[botulism|avian botulism]] in the Great Lakes region. |- | [[Image:Birdsinging03182006.JPG|100px]] || [[European starling#North America|European starlings]] || ''Sturnus vulgaris'' || Lower 48 states || Hunting, trapping || Introduced in 19th century [[American Acclimatization Society|as part of an effort to bring all species]] mentioned in [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare's]] works to the United States. 100 birds released in [[Central Park]] have spread all over the mainland U.S. |- | [[File:Boiga irregularis coiled.jpg|100px]] || [[Brown tree snake]] || ''Boiga irregularis'' || [[Guam]] || Dog-sniffing of incoming ships, [[paracetamol]] as poison || Has reached densities on Guam of up to 100 snakes per hectare, caused extinction on Guam of at least 12 bird species |- | [[File:Python molurus тигровый питон.jpg|100px]] || [[Burmese pythons in Florida|Burmese pythons]] || ''Python molarus'' || [[Everglades]] || Hunting season created || Introduced by hurricane damage to breeding facilities. |- | [[File:Apis mellifera scutellata 1355021.jpg|100px]] || [[Africanized bee]] || ''Apis'' hybrid || Southwestern U.S. || Cold weather has limited spread || Hybrid of African and European honeybees created in Brazil in the 1950s, described as "Killer bees." While individually no more poisonous than common honeybee, attacks are particularly violent and usually involve large numbers of stings, which can be cumulatively fatal to animals and people. |- | [[File:Grass carp fexx.jpg|100px]] || [[Asian carp]] || Multiple [[Cyprinidae]] || [[Mississippi River]] and tributaries || [[Rotenone]] poison, electric barriers || Have the habit of jumping out of the water, which can injure boaters. Introduced to eat algae in fish ponds in Southern U.S., escaped during flood events. |- | [[File:Adult Emerald Ash Borer on a penny.jpg|100px]] || [[Emerald ash borer]] || ''Agrilus planipennis'' || Eastern U.S. || Culling infected stands, bans on firewood transport || Threatens to severely reduce or eliminate the ash lumber industry of U.S., worth an estimated value of $25.1 billion per year |- | [[File:Adelges_tsugae_3225077.jpg|100px]] || [[Hemlock woolly adelgid]] || ''Adelges tsugae'' || Eastern U.S. || Insecticide treatment || Could kill most eastern hemlocks in the U.S. within the next decade |- | [[File:Rosa multiflora 1.jpg|100px]] || [[Multiflora rose]] || ''Rosa multiflora'' || Eastern U.S. || Manual removal, herbicides<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.invasivespeciesinfo.gov/plants/multiflorarose.shtml |title=Invasive Species: Plants - Multiflora Rose (Rosa multiflora) |publisher=Invasivespeciesinfo.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> || Introduced for erosion control and promoted as a "living fence" to attract wildlife, now competes with native understory plants |- | [[File:Cercopagidae GLERL 1.jpg|100px]] || [[Spiny waterflea]] || ''Bythotrephes longimanus'' || [[Great Lakes]] || Ballast water transport bans || Competes with native fish for prey, spines prevent many native fish from eating it as prey |- || [[File:Gabus 070909 0242 rwg.jpg|100px]] || [[Snakehead (fish)|Snakehead fish]] || ''Channa argus'' || [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]] [[fresh water]] || Since 2002 it has been illegal to possess a live snakehead in many U.S. states. As of July 2002, snakeheads are being sold in live fish food markets and some restaurants in Boston and New York. Live specimens have been confiscated by authorities in Alabama, California, Florida, Texas and Washington, all states where possession of these fish is illegal. Also, snakeheads are readily available for purchase over the Internet.<ref>http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/snakeheadfactsheetedited.pdf</ref> || Snakeheads can become invasive species and cause ecological damage because they are apex predators, meaning they have no natural enemies outside of their native environment. Each spawning-age female can release up to 15,000 eggs at once. Snakeheads can mate as often as five times a year. This means in just two years, a single female can release up to 150,000 eggs.{{Citation needed|date=June 2013}} |- || [[File:Snail in Ubud, Bali, 2010 (1).jpg|100px]] ||[[Giant African land snail|Giant African Snail]] || ''Lissachatina fulica'' || [[Florida]] [[Land]] || This invasive species was smuggled into Florida from Africa. The snails can grow up to be bigger than your fist. Since they need calcium to build their shells, they attach themselves to concrete or cement, which in many cases is house foundations, weakening houses. Another problem is that their eggs are so tiny and they breed very often. Florida is trying to keep the population down, they've even tried training dogs to find snails. || |- {{Citation needed|date= July 2017}} |}
==Economic impacts of invasive species==
The [[economic impacts of invasive species]] can be difficult to estimate, especially when an invasive species does not affect economically important native species. This is due in part to the difficulty in determining the [[non-use value]] of native habitats damaged by invasive species, and in part to incomplete knowledge of the effects of all of the invasive species present in the U.S. Estimates for the damages caused by well-known species can vary as well. The [[Office of Technology Assessment]] (OTA) has estimated [[zebra mussel]] economic effects at $300,000 a year, while an [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|ACoE]] study put the number at $1 billion. The United States government spends an estimated $1 billion to recover from the invasive Formosan termite, investing $300 million of this budget is spent in areas surround New Orleans, a major port city.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://is.cbr.tulane.edu/index.html|title=Louisiana Invasive Species|website=is.cbr.tulane.edu|access-date=2016-11-17}}</ref> Estimates of total yearly costs due to invasive species range from $1.1 billion per year to $137 billion per year.<ref name="nau">{{cite web|url=http://www.rmrs.nau.edu/invasive_species/ |title=Invasive Species Research - Rocky Mountain Research Station - USDA Forest Service |publisher=Rmrs.nau.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref>
In 1993, the OTA estimated that a total of $100 million is invested annually in invasive species aquatic weed control in the US.<ref>OTA, 1993. Harmful Non-Indigenous Species in the United States. Office of Technology Assessment, United States Congress, Washington, DC.</ref> Introduced rats cause more than $19 billion per year in damages,<ref>USDA, 2001. Agricultural Statistics. U.S. Department of Agriculture, Washington, DC</ref> exotic fish cause up to $5.4 billion annually, and the total costs of introduced weeds are estimated at around $27 billion annually.<ref>Pimentel, D., Lach, L., Zuniga, R., Morrison, D., 1999. Environmental and economic costs associated with introduced nonnative species in the United States. Manuscript, pp. 1– 28.</ref> The total damage to the U.S. native bird population due to invasive species is approximately $17 billion per year. Approximately $2.1 billion in forest products are lost each year to invasive plant pathogens in the United States, and a conservative estimate of the losses to U.S. livestock from exotic microbes and parasites was $9 billion per year in 2001.<ref>David Pimentel, Rodolfo Zuniga, Doug Morrison. Update on the environmental and economic costs associated with alien-invasive species in the United States. Ecological Economics. 52 (2005) 273-288</ref>
==Government policies and management efforts== The federal government has historically promoted the introduction and widespread distribution of species that would become invasive, including [[multiflora rose]], [[kudzu]], and others for numerous reasons. Before the 20th century, numerous species were imported and released without government oversight, such as the [[gypsy moth]] and [[house sparrow]]. Over 50% of flora recognized as invasive or noxious weeds were deliberately introduced to the United States, by either government policy or individuals.<ref>The United States Naturalized Flora: Largely the Product of Deliberate Introductions Richard N. Mack and Marianne Erneberg. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden. Vol. 89, No. 2 (Spring, 2002), pp. 176-189</ref> Current government policy can be broadly separated into two categories: preventing entry of a potential invasive species and controlling the spread of species already present. This is carried out by different government agencies, depending on what types of damage a species can cause. [[Image:RN Beetle galleries, Wych elm.JPG|thumb|right|[[Dutch elm disease]] was introduced accidentally through imported lumber in 1928]]
===Regulations designed to prevent entry of invasive species===
The [[Lacey Act of 1900]], originally designed to protect game wildlife, its role has increased to prohibit parties from bringing non-native species that have the potential to become invasive into the United States. The Lacey Act gives the [[United States Fish and Wildlife Service|FWS]] the power to list a species as "injurious" and regulate or prohibit its entry into the U.S.<ref>"Nation marks Lacey Act centennial, 100 years of federal wildlife law enforcement. US Fish and Wildlife Service. Retrieved on July 7, 2010.</ref> The [[Alien Species Prevention and Enforcement Act of 1992]] makes it illegal to transport a plant or animal deemed injurious into the United States through the mail. The FWS concerns itself mostly with the invasive species likely to threaten sensitive habitats or [[endangered species]].
The [[United States Department of Agriculture|USDA]] is also involved in preventing the introduction of invasive species, largely through the [[Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service]], or APHIS. APHIS was originally tasked with preventing damage to agriculture and forestry from alien species, pests, or diseases, but has had its mission expanded to include preventing invasive species spread as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aphis.usda.gov/about_aphis/ |title=Usda - Aphis - About Aphis |publisher=Aphis.usda.gov |date=2007-10-18 |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> This includes identifying potential pests and diseases, assisting in international and domestic eradication efforts, and the [[Smuggling Interdiction and Trade Compliance| Smuggling Interdiction and Trade Compliance Program]], designed initially to deal with illegally imported produce, but now tasked with preventing the entry of exotic pests, diseases, and potentially invasive species.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aphis.usda.gov/international_safeguarding/sitc/index.shtml |title=USDA - APHIS - International Safeguarding - Services |publisher=Aphis.usda.gov |date=2011-06-28 |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> APHIS also enforces bans against interstate transport of pests, diseases, and species listed as injurious, noxious weeds, or nuisance species. An example of the USDA banning imports is the ban on fresh [[mangosteen]] fruit due to concerns about fruit flies from southeast Asia. This ban originally allowed only frozen or canned fruit, but now allows for fresh irradiated fruit to enter.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/08/dining/08mang.html | work=The New York Times | title=Mangosteens Arrive, but Be Prepared to Pay | first=David | last=Karp | date=8 August 2007 | accessdate=22 May 2010}}</ref>
===Reducing the spread of dangerous invasive species===
Many invasive species are spread inadvertently by human activities, such as seeds stuck to clothing or mud transporting firewood, or through ballast water. The government has instituted several different policies related to different pathways the invasive species may be spread. For example, quarantines on a federal and state level exist for firewood across the Eastern United States in an attempt to halt the spread of the [[emerald ash borer]], [[gypsy moth]], [[oak wilt]], and others. Transporting firewood out of quarantine zones can result in a fine of up to $1,000,000 and 25 years in jail, but punishments are usually much lower.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dnr.wi.gov/invasives/firewood/ |title=Web Page Redirect - Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources |publisher=Dnr.wi.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref>
The techniques available for controlling the spread of invasive species can be broadly defined into 6 categories:<ref name="guidelines">"Guidelines for ranking invasive species control projects. Volume I." National Invasive Species Council. May, 2005. http://www.invasivespecies.gov/global/CMR/CMR_documents/NISC%20Control%20and%20Management%20Guidelines.pdf</ref> *Cultural practices **[[Controlled burn]]s and timbering. An example of this in action is the use of prescribed burns in the [[Everglades]] to control ''[[Melaleuca quinquenervia]]'' trees. The burns destroy ''Melaleuca'', but not native species which have adapted to wildfires, which were common, but are now suppressed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fws.gov/invasives/staffTrainingModule/methods/burning/practice.html |title=In Practice - Prescribed Burning: Management Methods - Managing Invasive Plants |publisher=Fws.gov |date=2009-02-18 |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> *Interference with dispersal **May include fencing, reducing accidental seed transport, and the construction of barriers, such as the electric barrier on the Chicago Sanitary & Ship Canal, discussed below. *Mechanical removal **Includes mowing, harvesting, manual removal, trapping, & culling. Many invasive plants, such as [[garlic mustard]], can regrow quickly after mowing and must be removed by the roots or chemically. *Chemical control **May include the use of any approved pesticide or herbicide, or vaccines to control invasive diseases. [[Sea lamprey]]s in the Great Lakes have had their numbers significantly reduced by a lampricide that kills larvae, which hatch in streams, before they can enter the lakes. The lampricide is responsible for reducing the sea lamprey population in the Great Lakes from over 3 million in the 1950s to around 450,000 today, and with potentially rescuing several Great Lakes fisheries.<ref name="echo">{{cite web|url=http://greatlakesecho.org/2009/05/11/pheromones-in-river-traps-attract-sea-lampreys/ |title=Pheromones in river traps attract sea lampreys |publisher=Great Lakes Echo |date=2009-05-11 |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> *Biological control **Can involve the release of specific predators/herbivores, parasites, or diseases designed to control an invasive species without damaging native ones. One example of this is the city of [[Chattanooga, Tennessee|Chattanooga's]] use of goats to control [[kudzu]] growing on mountain ridges. The goats, guarded from predators by llamas, eat the vine often enough to slowly starve the roots, killing the plant. This method is much cheaper than the repeated mowing or herbicidal spraying that would otherwise be necessary.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/05/us/05goats.html?ex=1338696000&en=cfc0f304b4a68bfc&ei=5088&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss | work=The New York Times | first=Theo | last=Emery | title=In Tennessee, Goats Eat the ‘Vine That Ate the South' | date=5 June 2007}}</ref> Goats reach areas which are inaccessible to machines and have multichambered stomachs which coupled with their grazing technique mean that goats leave few seeds behind to sprout again.<ref name=bbc_13Jan2015>{{cite web|last1=Jolly|first1=Joanna|title=The goats fighting America's plant invasion|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-30583512|website=BBC Magazine|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=15 January 2015}}</ref> *Interference with reproduction **This can include the release of mating-disrupting pheromones or the release of sterile males. Field tests are underway to study the control of [[sea lamprey]]s in the Great Lakes by the use of pheromone-baited traps in streams, in addition to current chemical controls. When female sea lampreys return to the stream to breed, they are drawn to the traps and captured, preventing reproduction from occurring.<ref name="echo"/>
An integrated pest management (IPM) approach, as defined by the National Invasive Species Council, uses scientific data and population monitoring to help determine the most efficient control strategy, which is usually a combination of several of the methods listed above. Agencies are encouraged to use an [[adaptive management]] strategy, involving regular reviews on the efficiency of their policies and conduct research into better methods.<ref name="guidelines"/>
===Inter-department co-operation=== Invasive species control is not overseen by one government agency. Eight agencies (divisions) of the [[United States Department of Agriculture]] (USDA) work on invasive species issues that include, [[Agricultural Research Service]] (ARS), [[Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service]] (APHIS), [[Cooperative State Research, Education, and Extension Service]] (CSREES), [[Economic Research Service]] (ERS), [[Farm Service Agency]] (FSA), [[Foreign Agricultural Service]] (FAS), [[United States Forest Service]] (FS), and the [[Natural Resources Conservation Service]] (NRCS).<ref>[https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.invasivespeciesinfo.gov%2Fdocs%2Fresources%2Fusdanoharm20100217.doc USDA "Do No Harm" 2009 Report]- Retrieved 2017-11-25</ref> Different invasive species are controlled by different agencies. For example, policies aimed at controlling the [[emerald ash borer]] are undertaken by the [[USDA]], because [[United States National Forest|National Forests]], the body coordinating emerald ash borer control efforts, are within the USDA.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stopthebeetle.info/ |title=Emerald Ash Borer Beetle (EAB) | Stop The Beetle |publisher=Stopthebeetle.info |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> The [http://www.invasivespecies.gov/ National Invasive Species Council] was created by executive order in 1999 and charged with promoting efficiency and coordination between the numerous federal invasive species prevention and control policies. The NISC is co-chaired by the secretaries of the three federal departments that are charged with invasive species control: [[United States Department of the Interior|Interior]], [[United States Department of Agriculture|Agriculture]], and [[United States Department of Commerce|Commerce]]. <ref>Emerton, L. and G. Howard, 2008, A Toolkit for the Economic Analysis of Invasive Species. Global Invasive Species Programme, Nairobi.</ref> Many state efforts use a similar council model to coordinate agencies within a state.
==Education and outreach== [[File:Zebra mussel warning sign.jpg|thumb|Warning signs like these are a first-line defense against the expansion of easily-spread invasive species, such as the [[zebra mussel]]]] Many of the policies used to contain invasive species, such as firewood transport bans or cleaning shoes and clothes after hiking are effective only when the general public knows of their existence and importance. Because of this numerous programs to inform the public about invasive species. This includes placing signs at boat ramps, campsites, state borders, hiking trails, and numerous other locations as reminders of policies and potential fines associated with breaking policies. There are also numerous government programs aimed at educating children,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.invasivespeciesinfo.gov/toolkit/outreach.shtml |title=Invasive Species: Manager's Tool Kit - Outreach Tools |publisher=Invasivespeciesinfo.gov |date=2012-03-14 |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> promoting volunteer efforts at removal, and the many ways citizens can prevent the spread of invasive species.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fws.gov/invasives/what-you-can-do.html |title=What Can You Do - Invasive Species - U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service |publisher=Fws.gov |date=2012-01-19 |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref>
==Invasive species by area==
===Great Lakes===
Current efforts in the [[Great Lakes]] [[ecoregion]] focus on measures that prevent the introduction of invasive species. As a major transport area, a [[Great Lakes#Invasive species|number of invasive species]] have already been established within the Great Lakes. In 1998, the United States Coast Guard, in accordance with the National Invasive Species Act of 1996, established a set of voluntary ballast water management program. In 2004 this voluntary program became mandatory for every ship entering US controlled waters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uscg.mil/hq/cg5/cg522/cg5224/bwm.asp |title=Ballast Water Management |publisher=Uscg.mil |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> Current measures are among the most stringent in the world and require ships entering from outside the [[Exclusive Economic Zone]] to flush ballast water in open seas or retain their ballast water for the length of their stay in the Great Lakes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greatlakes-seaway.com/en/environment/ballast-water/index.html |title=Seaway System - The Environment - Ballast Water |publisher=Greatlakes-seaway.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://serc.si.edu/labs/marine_invasions/vector_ecology/bw_exchange.aspx |title=SERC - Marine Invasions: Mid-ocean Ballast Water Exchange |publisher=Serc.si.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> Failure to comply with the US Coast Guards regulations can result in a class C felony.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uscg.mil/hq/cg5/cg522/cg5224/ans.asp |title=Aquatic Nuisance Species |publisher=Uscg.mil |date=2011-01-04 |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref>
Another preventative measure in the Great Lakes region is the presence of an electrified barrier in the [[Chicago Sanitary and Ship Canal]]. The barrier is meant to keep [[Asian carp]] from reaching Lake Michigan and the other Great Lakes. On December 2, 2010, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin were denied their request to force the closing the Canal by Judge Robert Dow of the United States District Court for Northern District of Illinois.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greatlakeslaw.org/blog/2010/12/another-setback-in-the-legal-fight-to-keep-asian-carp-out-of-the-great-lakes.html |title=Another setback in the legal fight to keep Asian carp out of the Great Lakes |publisher=Great Lakes Law |date=2010-12-06 |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greatlakeslaw.org/files/dist_ct_pi_opinion_order.pdf |title=Case: 1:10-cv-04457 Document #: 155 Filed: 12/02/10 Page 1 of 61 PageID #:4980 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> The closing of the Canal would have once again permanently separated Lake Michigan and the Mississippi river system. States argued that the canal, and the Asian carp in it, posed a risk to $7 billion worth of industry.<ref>{{cite web|last=Egan |first=Dan |url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/wisconsin/80731962.html |title=Illinois fights back over carp lawsuit |publisher=JSOnline |date=2010-01-05 |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> Currently the electric barrier is the only preventative measure and some question its effectiveness, particularly following the discovery of Asian carp DNA past the barrier.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/ci_17798637?nclick_check=1 |title=Chicago waterway gets third electric barrier aimed at keeping Asian carp out of Great Lakes |publisher=TwinCities.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> The discovery of DNA of Asian carp could be linked to live bait used around the Great Lakes region. The method for identifying the DNA is called environmental DNA (eDNA) surveillance. This method uses DNA, that is left in the environment, to identify species in low abundances.
===Rocky Mountain Region. ===
The [[USDA]] Rocky Mountain Research Station (RMRS) has a specific Invasive Species Working Group<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rmrs.nau.edu/invasive_species/iswg.php |title=Invasive Species Working Group - Rocky Mountain Research Station - USDA Forest Service |publisher=Rmrs.nau.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> to do the research about invasive species in Rocky Mountain region. The Invasive Species Working Group focuses on four key areas: (1) prediction and prevention, (2) early detection and rapid response, (3) control and management, and (4) restoration and rehabilitation.<ref name="nau"/> Specific approaches include prioritizing of invasive species problems, increased collaboration among agencies regarding those problems, and accountability for the responsible use of the limited resources available for invasive control.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.na.fs.fed.us/fhp/invasive_plants/strategic/framework.pdf |title=A Framework for the Development of the National Invasive Species Management Strategy for the USDA Forest Service |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref>
Invasive species of particular concern in the Rocky Mountain region include: [[cheatgrass]]; [[Euphorbia virgata|leafy spurge]]; [[tansy ragwort]]; [[spotted knapweed]]; bufflegrass; [[saltcedar]]; [[white pine blister rust]]; [[armillaria root rot]]; introduced trout species; golden algae; spruce aphid; and banded elm bark beetle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/rm/pubs_other/rmrs_2009_butler_j001.pdf |title=Research Summary and Expertise Directory |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref>
===Colorado River===
Already stressed by water management and damming, the Colorado River of Western United States is losing its big-river fish community to combined effects of predation and competition by introduced non-native fishes. This fish community includes four large fishes that are listed as endangered by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. One of these, the Colorado pikeminnow (AKA white or Colorado river salmon, Ptychocheilus lucius) is the largest minnow native to North America, and it is well known for its spectacular fresh water spawning migrations and homing ability. Despite a massive recovery effort, its numbers decline. Hampered by a loss of about 80% of its habitat, the young of this once abundant fish is overwhelmed in its nursery habitat by invasive small fishes (such as red shiner and fathead minnow), whose numbers are as high as 90% of the standing stocks. Its juveniles and adults now must also compete with and are preyed upon by introduced northern pike, channel and flathead catfishes, large and smallmouth basses, common carp, and other fishes.<ref>H.M. Tyus and J.F. Saunders 2000. Nonnative fish control and endangered fish recovery: Lessons from the Colorado River. Fisheries 25(9):17-24)</ref> However, the listing of these non native sport fish as invasive is controversial, as the fish are popular among anglers, who criticize the science used by government agencies and assert that nonnative species are largely a scapegoat in the decline of endemic Colorado River basin fish, blaming changes to the environment in the forms of dams and water diversions as being the main cause <ref>https://www.denverpost.com/2007/12/01/pike-at-heart-of-rifle-gap-discussion/</ref>
===Invasive species by state===
====Arizona==== {{See also|List of invasive plant species in Arizona}}
====California==== {{Main|List of invasive plant species in California|List of invasive species in California}} California has created a policy system towards invasive species, including Invasive Species Council of California (ISCC), California Invasive Species Advisory Committee (CISAC) and California Invasive Plant Council (Cal-IPC), a non-profit organization. The ISCC represents the highest level of leadership and authority in state government regarding invasive species. The ISCC is an inter-agency council that helps to coordinate and ensure complementary, cost-efficient, environmentally sound and effective state activities regarding invasive species. CISAC advises the ISCC, and created the [http://ice.ucdavis.edu/invasives/home/species California list of invasive species] California has many diverse [[Ecology of California|ecoregions]], and numerous endemic species that are at risk from invasive species.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iscc.ca.gov/ |title=Welcome to the Invasive Species Council of California |publisher=Iscc.ca.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref>
====Florida==== {{See also|List of invasive plant species in Florida|List of invasive species in Florida}}
=====Florida Everglades=====
{{See also|List of invasive species in the Everglades}} Invasive species in Florida currently make up more than 26% of the animal population and a full one third of the flora population.<ref>Ferriter, ''et al'' (2001) http://mytest.sfwmd.gov/portal/page/portal/pg_grp_sfwmd_sfer/portlet_prevreport/consolidated_01/chapter%2014/ch14.pdf</ref> In 1994, the [[Everglades Forever Act|Everglades Forever Act of 1994]] was passed to help in controlling Florida's water supply, recreation areas, and diverse flora and fauna.<ref>Florida Statutes Chapter 373.4592, {{cite web |url=http://exchange.law.miami.edu/everglades/statutes/state/florida/E_forever.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-05-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081028150828/http://exchange.law.miami.edu/everglades/statutes/state/florida/E_forever.htm |archivedate=2008-10-28 |df= }}</ref> In addition to control and prevention measures the act also calls for efforts to monitor the distribution of known invasive species.<ref>Ferriter, "et al" (2001) http://mytest.sfwmd.gov/portal/page/portal/pg_grp_sfwmd_sfer/portlet_prevreport/consolidated_01/chapter%2014/ch14.pdf</ref>
One invasive species occurring in the Everglades that can have serious consequences is the [[Burmese python]]. Between 2000 and 2010, approximately 1,300 of the snakes were removed from the Everglades.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.federalregister.gov/articles/2012/01/23/2012-1155/injurious-wildlife-species-listing-three-python-species-and-one-anaconda-species-as-injurious|title=Injurious Wildlife Species; Listing Three Python Species and One Anaconda Species as Injurious Reptiles|date=23 January 2012|publisher=Fish and Wildlife Service|accessdate=19 March 2012}}</ref> Currently the [[National Park Service]] is researching control measures for the Burmese python in order to limit the species effects on the delicate Everglades ecosystem.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/ever/naturescience/upload/PythonFactSheetLoRes.pdf |title=Natural Resources Management - Burmese Pythons |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref>
In 2015, the presence of the invasive land planarian ''[[Platydemus manokwari]]'' was recorded from several gardens in [[Miami]]. ''Platydemus manokwari'' is a predator of land snails and is considered a danger to endemic snails wherever it has been introduced.<ref name="JustineWinsor2015">{{cite journal|last1=Justine|first1=Jean-Lou|last2=Winsor|first2=Leigh|last3=Barrière|first3=Patrick|last4=Fanai|first4=Crispus|last5=Gey|first5=Delphine|last6=Han|first6=Andrew Wee Kien|last7=La Quay-Velázquez|first7=Giomara|last8=Lee|first8=Benjamin Paul Yi-Hann|last9=Lefevre|first9=Jean-Marc|last10=Meyer|first10=Jean-Yves|last11=Philippart|first11=David|last12=Robinson|first12=David G.|last13=Thévenot|first13=Jessica|last14=Tsatsia|first14=Francis|title=The invasive land planarianPlatydemus manokwari(Platyhelminthes, Geoplanidae): records from six new localities, including the first in the USA|journal=PeerJ|volume=3|year=2015|pages=e1037|issn=2167-8359|doi=10.7717/peerj.1037|url=https://peerj.com/articles/1037/|pmid=26131377|pmc=4485254}} {{open access}}</ref>
====Hawaii====
{{Main|Invasive species in Hawaii}} In Hawaii measures to prevent the introduction and spread of invasive species are coordinated by the Hawaii Invasive Species Council.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hawaiiinvasivespecies.org/hisc/ |title=Hawaii Invasive Species Council (HISC) |publisher=Hawaiiinvasivespecies.org |date=2003-10-29 |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> Currently the council is broken into five committees which focus on different areas of invasive species control. These focus areas are (1) prevention (2) management of established pests (3) increased public awareness (4) research and technology and (5) monetary resources.
Currently, Hawaii requires inspection of any and all plant, animal and microorganism transports.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hawaii.gov/hdoa/pi/pq |title=Plant Quarantine — Hawaii Department of Agriculture |publisher=Hawaii.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> This includes transports from the mainland in addition to transports occurring between islands. Travelers are required to fill out a [http://hawaii.gov/hdoa/pi/pq/Exhibit_3.pdf declaration form] for each journey. Failure to declare these transports can result in up to one year imprisonment or a $250,000 fine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hawaii.gov/hdoa/pi/pq/Exhibit_3.pdf |title=Exhibit 3. State of Hawaii Department of Agriculture Plants and Animals Declaration Form |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> Many potential invasives or carriers for invasives require permits and quarantine periods before entry to the state is allowed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hawaiiplants.com/importfaq.htm |title=Frequently Asked Questions on Import and Export Regulations of Plant Species |publisher=Hawaiiplants.com |date=2010-12-15 |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref>
In addition, there are other preventative measures such as a hotline for reporting sightings of known potential invaders like the [[Brown tree snake#Invasive species|brown tree snake]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hawaii.gov/hdoa/pi/pq/bts |title=Brown Tree Snake Program — Hawaii Department of Agriculture |publisher=Hawaii.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref>
{{See also|List of invasive plant species in Hawaii}}
====Idaho====
The Idaho Department of Agriculture (U.S.) has around 300 introduced or exotic species listed with 36 classified as [[noxious weed]]s (invasive{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} species). The legal designation of noxious weed for a plant species can use these four criteria:<ref name="Prather">{{cite book| last = Prather | first = Timothy | title = Idaho's Noxious Weeds | publisher = University of Idaho | year = 2002 }}</ref>
#It is present in but not native to state-province-ecosystem. #It is potentially more harmful than beneficial to that area. #Its management, control, or eradication is economically and physically feasible. #The potential adverse impact of it exceeds the cost of its control.
Some of the plants on Idaho's noxious weed list that are harmful or poisonous are: *[[Leafy spurge]]: native to [[Eurasia]]. It has a milky latex in all its parts that can produce [[blisters]] and [[dermatitis]] in humans, cattle, and horses and may cause permanent blindness if rubbed into an eye. *[[Poison hemlock]]: native to Europe. It contains highly poisonous [[alkaloids]] toxic to all classes of domesticated grazing animals. ''[[Agonopterix alstroemeriana]]'' is used as a biological control method for the plant, which in high larval numbers can kill large areas of the poisonous plant. *[[Russian knapweed]]: native to the Caucasus in southern Russia and Asia. It causes [[chewing disease]] in horses. *Tansy ragwort: native to Eurasia. All parts are poisonous, it causes liver damage to cattle and horses, while it affects sheep to a lesser extent. *[[Toothed spurge]]: native to the [[Great Plains]] region. A milky latex exists in all parts of the plant that can produce blisters and dermatitis in humans, cattle, and horses. It may cause permanent blindness if rubbed into the eye. *[[Yellow starthistle]]: native to the [[Mediterranean basin]] area and Asia. It causes death and chewing disease in horses. *[[Yellow toadflax]]: native to Europe. It contains a poisonous [[glucoside]] that may be harmful to livestock. '''Louisiana'''
The city of New Orleans, the "gateway to the Mississippi", is a porous port city with rich soils. In turn, many aquatic plants are introduced to the region, making Louisiana the state with the second largest list of invasive aquatic species,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nas.er.usgs.gov/|title=Nonindigenous Aquatic Species|website=nas.er.usgs.gov|access-date=2016-11-17}}</ref> second to Florida.
The "Dirty Dozen"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2015/02/23/like-most-invasive-species-pythons-are-in-the-u-s-to-stay/|title=The dirty dozen: 12 of the most destructive invasive animals in the United States|website=Washington Post|access-date=2016-11-17}}</ref> details a list of the United States' most destructive invasive species. Of the twelve, four are identified in the state, including the [[zebra mussel]], tamarisk, [[hydrilla]], and [[Triadica sebifera|Chinese tallow]].
====Maryland==== {{See also|List of invasive plant species in Maryland}}
====Nevada==== {{See also|List of invasive plant species in Nevada}}
====New Jersey==== {{See also|List of invasive plant species in New Jersey}}
====New Mexico==== {{See also|List of invasive plant species in New Mexico}}
====New York==== [[File:Wineberry - closeup.jpg|thumb|upright|Invasive wineberry found in Rye, New York]] [[File:Multiflora rose closeup.jpg|thumb|upright|Multiflora rose closeup, Rye, New York]] Invasive species pose a threat to wildlife, habitat, waterways, economy, and the health of humans in New York State. The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation ([[NYSDEC]]) works with stewards of natural resources, non-profits and citizen scientists to detect, record and manage invasive species. These collaborations are organized into 8 Partnerships for Regional Invasive Species Management (PRISMs) throughout NYS. THE PRISMS were formed under Title 17, Environmental Conservation Law 9-1705(5)(g).
According to NYSDEC <ref>NYSDEC PRISM Fact Sheet, http://www.dec.ny.gov/docs/lands_forests_pdf/prismfactsheet.pdf</ref> PRISMS perform the following tasks: plan regional invasive species management;develop early detection and rapid response capacity;implement eradication projects; educate the public in cooperation with DEC contracted Education and Outreach providers; coordinate PRISM partners; recruit and train volunteers; support research through citizen science. <ref>NY Invasive Species Information, http://nyis.info/index.php</ref>
Terrestrial species of high concern in New York include *''[[Acer platanoides]]'' — Norway maple *''[[Ailanthus altissima]]'' — Tree of heaven *''[[Alliaria petiolata]]'' — Garlic mustard *''[[Ampelopsis glandulosa]]'' — Porcelain berry *''[[Aralia elata]]'' — Japanese angelica tree *''[[Artemisia vulgaris]]'' — Mugwort *''[[Berberis thunbergii]]'' — Japanese barberry *''[[Celastrus orbiculatus]]'' — Asian bittersweet *''[[Euonymus alatus]]'' — Burning bush *''[[Fallopia japonica]]'' — Japanese knotweed *''[[Lonicera japonica]]'' — Japanese honeysuckle *''[[Lonicera maackii]]'' — Bush honeysuckle *''[[Microstegium vimineum]]'' — Japanese stiltgrass *''[[Miscanthus sinensis]]'' — Chinese silvergrass *''[[Lesser celandine|Ranunculus ficaria]]'' — Lesser celandine *''[[Rosa multiflora]]'' — Multiflora rose *''[[Rubus phoenicolasius]]'' — Wineberry
Aquatic species of high concern in New York include *''[[Trapa natans]]'' — European Water chestnut *''[[Myriophyllum spicatum]]'' — Eurasian Watermilfoil *''[[Hydrilla verticillata]]'' — Hydrilla
Insects *''[[Anoplophora glabripennis]]'' — Asian Longhorned Beetle *''[[Agrilus planipennis]]'' — Emerald Ash Borer
==See also== *[[List of invasive species in North America]] *[[List of invasive species in the Mid-Atlantic region of the United States]] *[[Environmental issues in the United States]] *[[Fauna of the United States]]
==References== {{Reflist|2|refs=Nathan, L. R., Jerde, C. L., Budny, M. L., & Mahon, A. R. (2015). The use of environmental DNA in invasive species surveillance of the Great Lakes commercial bait trade. Conservation Biology, 29(2), 430–439. http://doi.org/10.1111/cobi.12381}}

Lists general information and resources for invasive species. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060920215911/http://www.blm.gov/weeds/ Weeds] at the Bureau of Land Management *[http://app.thearit.com/nature-conservancy/thenatureconservancysgreatlakesproject.html The Nature Conservancy's Great Lakes Project- Aquatic Invasive Species] *[http://plants.usda.gov/java/noxiousDriver Invasive and Noxious Weeds] the Department of Agriculture ([[USDA]]) *[http://www.aphis.usda.gov/plant_health/plant_pest_info/weeds/ Noxious Weed Program] at the Department of Agriculture
;By state *[http://www.weedawareness.org/ Montana's Weed Awareness Program: Pulling Together] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20010602024237/http://dnr.metrokc.gov/wlr/LANDS/weeds/weedid.htm Noxious Weed Photos, King County, Washington State] *[http://www.cal-ipc.org/ip/definitions/index.php cal-ipc: "Noxious Weed definitions"] -->

The '''Kevin Lynch Award''' of the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]'s Department of Urban Studies and Planning, established in 1988, is named in honor of the urban planner and author [[Kevin A. Lynch]]. It is given to individuals or organizations which contribute to research in city form.<ref>"Kevin Lynch Award", MIT Urban Planning Department [https://dusp.mit.edu/cdd/project/kevin-lynch-award-0]</ref>
==Honorees==
Starting in 2014, the awards have been presented in five categories. Earlier awards have been retroactively assigned to these categories.
Past winners:<ref>"Lynch Award: Past Winners" [http://dusp.mit.edu/project/lynch-award-past-winners]</ref>
===Technology and Media in City Imaging===
:[[Jennifer Pahlka]] and [[Code for America]] (2014) :[[Manuel Castells]] (2001) :[[Richard Saul Wurman]] (1991)
===Ecological Sustainability in City Form===
* [[Randolph T. Hester]] (2011) * [[Richard M. Daley]] (2005)
===Preservation and Change in City Image===
:[[Barnaby Evans]] and [[William D. Warner]] (2003) :[[Allan Jacobs]] (1999) :[[William L. MacDonald]] (1989)
===Justice and Efficiency in City Design===
* City of Vancouver Planning Department (2007) * [[Allan Heskin]] (1990s) * [[Eric Wolf]] (1989)
===Urban Events and Ephemera===
:Barnaby Evans (2003) :[[First Night#Boston|Boston’s First Night]] (1990)
==External links==

revision.text:
[[Image:lensspeed.jpg|frame|right|A fast prime (fixed focal length) lens, the Canon 50mm {{f/}}1.4 (left), and a slower zoom lens, the Canon 18–55mm {{f/}}3.5–5.6 (right); this lens is faster at 18mm than it is at 55mm.]] '''Lens speed''' refers to the maximum [[aperture]] diameter, or minimum [[f-number]], of a [[photographic lens]]. A lens with a larger maximum aperture (that is, a smaller minimum f-number) is called a "fast lens" because it can achieve the same exposure with a faster [[shutter speed]]. Conversely, a smaller maximum aperture (larger minimum f-number) is "slow" because it delivers less light intensity and requires a slower (longer) shutter speed.
A fast lens speed is desirable in taking pictures in dim light, or with long [[telephoto]] lenses and for controlling [[depth of field]] and [[bokeh]], especially in portrait photography,<ref>Waldren, Margaret (and others) ''Advanced Digital Photography'' 2004 Media Publishing</ref> and for [[sports photography]] and [[photojournalism]].
Lenses may also be referred to as being "faster" or "slower" than one another; so an {{f/|3.5|link=yes}} lens can be described as faster than an {{f/}}5.6.
==Tradeoffs== Attaining maximum lens speed requires engineering tradeoffs, and as such, "[[prime lens|prime]]" (fixed focal length) lenses are generally faster than [[zoom lens]]es, and modern manual-focus lenses are generally faster than their autofocus counterparts.<ref>Long, Ben ''Complete Digital Photography'' 2004 Charles River Media</ref>
With 35mm cameras, the fastest lenses are typically in the "[[normal lens]]" range near 50mm and there are several high-quality fast lenses available that are relatively inexpensive. For example, the [[Canon EF 50mm f/1.8 II|Canon EF 50mm {{f/}}1.8 II]] or [[Nikon AF Nikkor 50 mm f/1.8D|Nikon AF Nikkor 50mm {{f/}}1.8D]] are very inexpensive, but quite fast and optically well-regarded. Old fast manual focus lenses, just as the Nikkor-S(C) or Nikkor AI-S 50mm {{f/}}1.4, were historically produced abundantly, and are thus sold relatively inexpensively on the used lens market.
Especially outside of the "normal lenses", lens speed also tends to correlate with the price and/or quality of the lens. This is because lenses with larger maximum apertures require greater care with regard to design, precision of manufacture, special coatings and quality of glass. At wide apertures, [[spherical aberration]] becomes more significant and must be corrected. Faster [[telephoto]] and wide-angle [[retrofocus]] designs tend to be much more expensive.
==Fast lenses== The fastest lenses in general production now are {{f/}}1.2 or {{f/}}1.4, with more at {{f/}}1.8 and {{f/}}2.0, and many at {{f/}}2.8 or slower. What is considered "fast" has evolved to lower f-numbers over the years, due to advances in [[lens design]], [[optical manufacturing]], quality of glass, [[optical coating]]s, and the move toward smaller imaging formats. For example, the [[1911 Encyclopædia Britannica]] states that "...[Lenses] are also sometimes classified according to their rapidity, as expressed by their effective apertures, into extra rapid, with apertures larger than {{f/}}6; rapid, with apertures from {{f/}}6 to {{f/}}8; slow, with apertures less than {{f/}}11."
[[Image:Canon 85mm comparison (front).jpg|thumb|250px|[[Canon EF 85mm lens|Canon 85mm {{f/}}1.8 and {{f/}}1.2]] showing their large [[entrance pupil]]s]] For scale, note that {{f/}}0.5, {{f/}}0.7, {{f/}}1.0, {{f/}}1.4, and {{f/}}2.0 are each 1 f-stop apart (2× as fast), as an f-stop corresponds to a factor of [[square root of 2]], about 1.4. Thus around {{f/}}1.0, a change of 0.1 corresponds to about 1/4 of an f-stop (by [[linear approximation]]): {{f/}}1.0 is about 50% faster than {{f/}}1.2, which is about 50% faster than {{f/}}1.4.
{{as of|2017}}, Canon, Nikon, Pentax and Sony all make an autofocus 50mm {{f/}}1.4 lens. These are not unusual lenses and are relatively inexpensive. Canon also makes autofocus 50mm and 85mm {{f/}}1.2 lenses, while Nikon makes a manual focus 50mm {{f/}}1.2 lens and an autofocus 85mm {{f/}}1.4; see [[Canon EF 50mm lens]]es and [[Canon EF 85mm lens]]es for details. Pentax makes a 50mm {{f/}}1.4 lens and 55mm {{f/}}1.4 lens for [[APS-C]] cameras; see [[Pentax lenses]]. Sony makes a 50mm {{f/}}1.4 lens which is a continuation of the [[Minolta AF 50mm f/1.4 lens|Minolta AF 50mm {{f/}}1.4 lens]], and two lenses with Carl Zeiss: a 50mm {{f/}}1.4 and 85mm {{f/}}1.4.
The maximum [[exposure time]] in free-hand photography can be enhanced even more also for fast lenses, if the camera is equipped with an [[image stabilisation]] system. In 2014 [[Panasonic]] introduced the fastest lens with in-built stabilisation, the [[Leica Camera|Leica]] [[Nocticron]] 42.5 mm f/1.2, which in the meantime even can be operated with dual image stabilisation (Dual I.S.), provided that the camera body has an additional [[Image stabilization#Sensor-shift|stabilising system at the image sensor]], too.
In the mid 60s there was something of a fad for fast lenses among the major manufacturers.<ref name=Maiello2000 /> In 1966 in response to the trend [[Carl Zeiss]] displayed a prop lens christened the Super-Q-Gigantar 40mm {{f/}}0.33 at [[photokina 1966|photokina]].<ref name=Maiello2000 /> Made from various parts found around the factory (the lenses came from a [[Enlarger#Types of Enlarger|darkroom condenser enlarger]]), the claimed speed and focal lengths were purely nominal and it wasn't usable for photography.<ref name=Maiello2000>{{cite web |url=http://www.nadir.it/pandora/ZEISS.htm |title=L'OBIETTIVO PIU' LUMINOSO DEL MONDO |last1=Maiello |first1=Agostino |date=January 2000 |website=Nadir.it |publisher=Nadir Magazine |accessdate=28 September 2013|language=Italian}}</ref><ref name=Zhang2013>{{cite web |url=http://petapixel.com/2013/08/06/carl-zeiss-super-q-gigantar-40mm-f0-33-the-fastest-lens-ever-made/ |title=Carl Zeiss Super-Q-Gigantar 40mm {{f/}}0.33: The Fastest Lens Ever Made? |last1=Zhang |first1=Michael |date=August 6, 2013 |website=Petapixel |accessdate=28 September 2013}}</ref>
=== Maximum possible speed === Ultimately, the speed of a lens is limited by mechanical constraints of the camera system (shutter or mirror clearance, [[lens mount|mount]] diameter). The smallest possible [[working f-number]] is
:<math>N_\text{min} = \frac{1}{2\;\mathrm{NA}_\text{max}} = \frac{1}{2\,n \sin\theta}</math>
where * NA<sub>max</sub> is the largest possible [[numerical aperture]], * {{var|n}} is the [[index of refraction]] of the medium behind the lens, most often air where {{var|n}} = 1, * {{var|θ}} is the half-angle of the maximum cone of light that can reach the film or sensor.
This sets a limit close to {{f/}}1.0 to {{f/}}1.2 for most [[Single-lens reflex camera|SLR]] mounts, whereas lenses for [[Rangefinder camera|rangefinder]] and [[Mirrorless camera|mirrorless]] cameras can be faster, as they can be brought closer to the image plane. Reproduction lenses incapable of infinity focus can have nominal f-numbers smaller than this limit, as the limit applies to the ''working'' f-number (the f-number corrected by the [[Bellows (photography)|bellows factor]]), not to the nominal f-number. It should be noted that only the working f-number correctly assesses the light gathering power of the lens.
Since {{math|sin θ < 1}}, it follows that no lens can be faster than {{f/}}0.5 if it operates in air. Lenses can be made faster than this by requiring the film emulsion to be in physical contact with the rear element, thus eliminating the air gap between the lens and the emulsion. Another option is to use [[oil immersion]] techniques.
=== List of ultrafast lenses === Some of the fastest camera lenses in production {{as of|2017|lc=on}} were as follows:
* Handevision Ibelux 40mm {{f/}}0.85, Made for multiple camera mounts including Micro 4/3, Sony E-Mount and Fujifilm X-Mount * [[Fujinon]] 43mm {{f/}}0.85 * [[Cosina Voigtländer]] Nokton 17.5mm {{f/}}0.95 Aspherical [[Micro Four Thirds system|Micro Four Thirds]] mount<ref>{{cite web | title = Cosina Voigtänder — Nokton 17.5mm F0.95 Aspherical | publisher = [[Cosina Voigtländer]] }}</ref><ref name="Cosina Voigtländer">{{cite web | url = http://www.cosina.co.jp/seihin/voigt/v-lens/micro-ft/ | title = Cosina Voigtänder - Nokton 25mm F0.95 | date = 2010-08-26 | publisher = [[Cosina Voigtländer]] | accessdate = 2013-12-03 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/product/855215-REG/Voigtlander_BA175M_Nokton_17_5mm_f_0_95_Lens.html The Voigtlander 17.5mm {{f/}}0.95 at B&H Photo]</ref> * [[Cosina Voigtländer]] Nokton 25mm {{f/}}0.95 [[Micro Four Thirds system|Micro Four Thirds]] mount<ref name="Cosina Voigtländer"/><ref>[http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/product/754598-REG/Voigtlander_BA305A_Nokton_25mm_f_0_95_Lens.html The Voigtlander 25mm {{f/}}0.95 at B&H Photo]</ref> * [[Cosina Voigtländer]] Nokton 42.5mm {{f/}}0.95 [[Micro Four Thirds system|Micro Four Thirds]] mount<ref name="Cosina Voigtländer"/><ref>[http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/product/1000625-REG/voigtlander_ba425m_nokton_42_5mm_f_0_95_micro.html The Voigtlander 42.5mm {{f/}}0.95 at B&H Photo]</ref> * [[Leica Camera|Leica]] Noctilux-M 50mm {{f/}}0.95 ASPH announced on September 15, 2008, it is one of the fastest [[aspherical lens]] to have ever reached mass production, with a MSRP of £6290 (approximately US$10,000).<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.dpreview.com/news/0809/08091505leica_50mm_f0_95.asp | title = Leica offers World's fastest Aspherical lens | date = 2008-09-15 | publisher = [[Leica Camera]] | accessdate = 2009-02-14 }}</ref> *SLR Magic HyperPrime LM 50mm T0.95 ({{f/}}0.92) * [[Noktor]] 50mm {{f/}}0.95 'HyperPrime'<ref>{{cite web | url = http://noktor.com/products.php | title = NOKTOR – Ultra Fast Lenses | accessdate = 2010-05-26 }}</ref> a fast CCTV lens design adapted for the [[Micro Four Thirds system]]<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.kenrockwell.com/tech/noktor/index.htm | title = KenRockwell.com – Noktor 50mm f/0.95 | accessdate = 2011-11-22 }}</ref> * SLR Magic 25mm T/0.95 * SLR Magic 35mm T/0.95 * [[Shenyang Zhongyi Mitakon Speedmaster 50 mm f/0.95|Mitakon 50mm]] and 35mm {{f/}}0.95 * Vantage One T/1.0 Cine lenses - 17.5mm to 120mm Super35mm Spherical Primes. * Metabones 0.58x BMPCC Speed Booster (for Blackmagic Pocket Cinema Camera) combined with an {{f/}}1.2 SLR lens to yield {{f/}}0.74 or combined with an {{f/}}1.4 SLR lens to yield {{f/}}0.80 <ref>{{Cite web|title = F0.74 - new Metabones Speed Boosters break boundaries - EOSHD|url = http://www.eoshd.com/2013/12/metabones-speed-booster-blackmagic-cameras-bmcc-bmpcc/|website = EOSHD|accessdate = 2015-11-19|language = en-US}}</ref> * Metabones 0.64x Speed Booster XL (for Micro Four Thirds format) combined with an {{f/}}1.2 SLR lens to yield {{f/}}0.80 or combined with an {{f/}}1.4 SLR lens to yield {{f/}}0.90<ref>{{Cite web|title = Metabones introduces Speed Booster XL 0.64x for Panasonic GH4|url = http://www.dpreview.com/articles/9958618251/metabones-introduces-speed-booster-xl-0-64x-for-panasonic-gh4|website = dpreview.com|accessdate = 2015-11-19}}</ref> * Metabones 0.71x Speed Booster ULTRA (for either Micro Four Thirds or APS-C formats) combined with an {{f/}}1.2 SLR lens to yield {{f/}}0.90 or combined with an {{f/}}1.4 SLR lens to yield {{f/}}1.0<ref>{{Cite web|title = Official announcement - {{redirect|Level quantity||Level measurement}}
In the [[ISO/IEC 80000|International System of Quantities]], the '''level''' of a quantity is the [[logarithm]] of the ratio of the value of that quantity to a reference value of the same quantity.<ref>[[ISO 80000-3|ISO 80000-3:2006, ''Quantities and units'', Part 2: Space and Time]]</ref><ref>W. M. Carey, Sound Sources and Levels in the Ocean, IEEE J Oceanic Eng 31:61–75(2006)</ref> Examples are the various types of [[Sound level (disambiguation)|sound level]]<!--intentional link to DAB page-->: [[sound power level]] (literally, the level of the [[sound power]], abbreviated SWL), [[sound exposure level]] (SEL), [[sound pressure level]] (SPL) and [[particle velocity level]] (SVL).<ref>[[ISO 80000-8|ISO 80000-8:2007, ''Quantities and units'', Part 8: Acoustics]]</ref>
==Definitions== Level and its units are defined in [[ISO 80000-3#Logarithmic quantities and units|ISO 80000-3]].
===Level=== Level of a quantity ''Q'', denoted ''L''<sub>''Q''</sub>, is defined by<ref>ANSI S1.1-2013 Acoustical Terminology, entry 3.01</ref> :<math>L_Q = \log_r\!\left(\frac{Q}{Q_0}\right)\!,</math> where *''r'' is the base of the logarithm; *''Q'' is the quantity; *''Q''<sub>0</sub> is the reference value of ''Q''.
===Level of a root-power quantity{{anchor|Root-power quantities|Field quantities}}=== The level of a ''root-power'' quantity (also known as a ''field'' quantity), denoted ''L''<sub>''F''</sub>, is defined by <ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Francesco_Damore3/publication/316104462_Effect_of_moisturizer_and_lubricant_on_the_finger-surface_sliding_contact_tribological_and_dynamical_analysis/links/58f9e4f2a6fdcc73cf270e91/Effect-of-moisturizer-and-lubricant-on-the-finger-surface-sliding-contact-tribological-and-dynamical-analysis.pdf e Industriale, F. D. I. C., & D'Amore, F. Effect of moisturizer and lubricant on the finger‒surface sliding contact: tribological and dynamical analysis.]</ref> :<math>L_F = \log_{\mathrm{e}}\!\left(\frac{F}{F_0}\right)\!,</math> where *''F'' is the root-power quantity, proportional to the square root of power quantity; *''F''<sub>0</sub> is the reference value of ''F''. For the level of a root-power quantity, the base of the logarithm is {{nowrap|1=''r'' = [[e (mathematical constant)|e]]}}.
===Level of a power quantity{{anchor|Power quantities}}=== Level of a ''power'' quantity, denoted ''L''<sub>''P''</sub>, is defined by :<math>L_P = \log_{\mathrm{e}^2}\!\left(\frac{P}{P_0}\right) = \frac{1}{2} \ln\!\left(\frac{P}{P_0}\right)\!,</math> where *''P'' is the power quantity; *''P''<sub>0</sub> is the reference value of ''P''. For the level of a power quantity, the base of the logarithm is {{nowrap|1=''r'' = e<sup>2</sup>}}.<ref>Ainslie, M. A. A Century of Sonar: Planetary Oceanography, Underwater Noise Monitoring, and the Terminology of Underwater Sound. [http://acousticstoday.org/a-century-of-sonar-planetary-oceanography-underwater-noise-monitoring-and-the-terminology-of-underwater-sound-michael-a-ainslie/ Acoustics Today], 23 February 2015</ref>
==Units of level==
===Power level === {{see also|Decibel#Conversions|Neper#Units}}
The [[neper]], [[Decibel|bel]], and [[decibel]] (one tenth of a bel) are units of level that are often applied to such quantities as power, intensity, or gain.<ref>{{cite book | author=Barry Taylor | year=1995 | title=Guide for the Use of the International System of Units (SI): The Metric System | publisher=Diane Publishing Co. | page=28 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I3HRRrDd1n8C&pg=PA28}}</ref> The neper, bel, and decibel are defined by *{{nowrap|1=Np = 1}}; *{{nowrap|1=B = {{sfrac|1|2}} log<sub>e</sub>10 Np}}; *{{nowrap|1=dB = 0.1 B = {{sfrac|1|20}} log<sub>e</sub>10 Np}}.
If ''F'' is a root-power quantity: :<math>L_F = \log_{\mathrm{e}}\!\left(\frac{F}{F_0}\right)\!~\mathrm{Np} = 2 \log_{10}\!\left(\frac{F}{F_0}\right)\!~\mathrm{B} = 20 \log_{10}\!\left(\frac{F}{F_0}\right)\!~\mathrm{dB}.</math>
If ''P'' is a power quantity: :<math>L_P = \frac{1}{2} \log_{\mathrm{e}}\!\left(\frac{P}{P_0}\right)\!~\mathrm{Np} = \log_{10}\!\left(\frac{P}{P_0}\right)\!~\mathrm{B} = 10 \log_{10}\!\left(\frac{P}{P_0}\right)\!~\mathrm{dB}.</math>
If the power quantity ''P'' is proportional to ''F''<sup>2</sup>, and if the reference value of the power quantity, ''P''<sub>0</sub>, is in the same proportion to ''F''<sub>0</sub><sup>2</sup>, the levels ''L''<sub>''F''</sub> and ''L''<sub>''P''</sub> are equal.
===Frequency level=== The [[Octave (electronics)|octave]] is a unit of level (specifically "frequency level",<ref>Fletcher, H. (1934). Loudness, pitch and the timbre of musical tones and their relation to the intensity, the frequency and the overtone structure. The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America, 6(2), 59–69.</ref> for {{nowrap|1=''r'' = 2}}) though that concept is seldom seen outside of the ANSI standard that defines it.<ref>[[ANSI/ASA S1.1-2013|ANSI/ASA S1.1-2013, ''Acoustical Terminology'']]</ref> A [[semitone]] is one twelfth of an octave. A [[Cent (music)|cent]] is one hundredth of a semitone.
==See also== * {{section link|Decibel|Definition}} * [[Field, power, and root-power quantities]] * [[Logarithmic scale]] * [[Sound level (disambiguation)]] * [[Leveling (tapered floating point)]] * [[Level-index arithmetic]] (LI) and [[symmetric level-index arithmetic]] (SLI)
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Mathematical terminology]] [[Category:Logarithmic scales of measurement]]

revision.text:
{{external links|date=July 2013}}
'''Low information rationality''' is a [[social theory]] that states that people are [[information]] consumers with limited benefits and time for processing and understanding information. Due to the limited benefits and time individuals have for learning new information, individuals use various shortcuts and [[heuristics]] to understand information quicker. Simply put, it does not make sense for the average individual to develop in depth understandings of most issues. The theory is often used to explain the limited understanding of [[politics]] and [[Science|scientific]] [[Technology|technologies]] by the general [[public]].
==Assumptions== The concept of low-information rationality is based on the assumption that [[human being]]s are [[cognitive miser]]s and minimize the economic costs of making decisions and forming attitudes. Most citizens will therefore not bother to develop an in-depth understanding of political or scientific issues, which would require significant time and effort. Rather, they collect only as much information as they think is necessary to make any given decision.<ref name="Messages and Heuristics">{{cite web|url=http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/stellent/groups/corporatesite/@msh_publishing_group/documents/web_document/wtx032691.pdf|title=3 MESSAGES AND HEURISTICS: HOW AUDIENCES FORM ATTITUDES ABOUT EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES|last=Scheufele|first=Dietram|work=Engaging Science: Thoughts, deeds, analysis and action|accessdate=15 May 2013}}</ref>
==Key mechanisms== The reason this theory comes about in today's age is due to vast increase in amount of information that each of us is exposed to through the [[internet]], [[Smartphone|smart phones]], and [[Television|TV]]. Therefore, these patterns of [[information processing]] make perfect sense for citizens who have to deal with thousands of pieces of new information every day, and we all use them. We spend less [[Cognition|cognitive]] effort in buying toothpaste than we do when picking a new car. And that difference in [[Information seeking|information-seeking]] is largely a function of the costs.<ref name="Messages and Heuristics" />
==Shortcuts== There are a variety of shortcuts individuals use to process information quickly and more efficiently. This does not mean, however, that these methods always lead to accurate and reliable conclusions. Common shortcuts include, [[stereotypes]], opinions of others, interpersonal influences, [[Framing (social sciences)|news frames]], [[heuristic]]s and [[political ideology]].
==Samuel Popkin: ''The Reasoning Voter''== American pollster and political scientist [[Samuel L. Popkin|Samuel Popkin]] coined the term "low-information" in 1991 when he used the phrase "low-information signaling" in his book ''The Reasoning Voter: Communication and Persuasion in Presidential Campaigns.''<ref name="popkin">{{cite book|last=Popkin|first=Samuel|title=The Reasoning Voter|year=1991|publisher=The University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago, IL|isbn=0226675440|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fAT-IREgyQ8C&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> Popkin relies on a theory of low information rationality to explain how voters are able to make rational choices between candidates. Voters do this by using information shortcuts that they receive during campaigns, usually using something like a "drunkard's search." Voters use small amounts of personal information to construct a narrative about candidates. Essentially, they ask themselves this: "Based on what I know about the candidate personally, what is the probability that this presidential candidate was a good governor? What is the probability that he will be a good president?" Popkin's analysis is based on one main premise: voters use low information rationality gained in their daily lives, through the media and through personal interactions, to evaluate candidates and facilitate electoral choices.
==Other models== The science Literacy/[[knowledge deficit]] model states that the public is willing and able to process information if it is available. Therefore, a lack of public support or participation is caused by a lack of information available to the public.
==Problems for science== As mentioned above, scientists who use the knowledge deficit model face great difficulty conveying information to the lay public when overwhelming amount of psychology and political science studies show that the public uses the low information rationality model. Some examples of this are in the cutting-edge sciences of [[nanotechnology]] and biotechnology.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Brossard, D. |author2=Shanahan, J. |author3=Nesbitt, T.C. |title=The Public, the Media, and Biotechnology|year=2007|publisher=CABI|location=UK|isbn=978 1 84593 204 6|page=231}}</ref>
For issues such as [[agricultural biotechnology]], for example, where developing an in-depth understanding would require significant efforts on the part of ordinary citizens, the pay-offs in terms of being able to make informed policy judgments may simply not be enough. As a result, it makes perfect sense for citizens to rely on shortcuts such as opinions of others when forming their own opinions and trying to make sense of different policy positions.
== See also == * [[Low-information voter]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * http://abstractpolitics.com/2011/05/the-party-faithful-partisan-images-candidate-religion-and-the-electoral-impact-of-party-identification/
